questions.prompt: In BG 14.1, what does Arjuna ask Krishna?
choices: Teach me about the three modes of nature and their effects
questions.feedback: Arjuna seeks to understand the three gunas and their influence.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.3, what is the great womb from which all beings are born?
choices: My womb is the great Brahman; all beings are conceived in it
questions.feedback: Krishna is the source of all existence through His transcendental nature.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.4, what does Krishna describe about His creative function?
choices: All forms are born from me; I am the father; prakriti is the womb
questions.feedback: Krishna and His material energy combine to manifest all existence.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.5 teach about the three modes?
choices: Sattva (goodness), rajas (passion), and tamas (ignorance) bind the eternal soul
questions.feedback: The three qualities are the basic constituents of material nature.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.6, what is the characteristic of sattva (goodness)?
choices: Pure, luminous, and free from sinfulness; binds through knowledge and happiness
questions.feedback: Sattva is the purest mode and leads toward spiritual elevation.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.7, what is the nature of rajas (passion)?
choices: The embodiment of desire and attachment; causes action and craving
questions.feedback: Passion creates restlessness and desire-driven action.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.8 teach about tamas (ignorance)?
choices: Darkness, delusion, and laziness; binds the living being through illusion
questions.feedback: Ignorance is the most degrading mode, creating delusion and inertia.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.10, what happens when sattva predominates?
choices: The symptoms of purity appear; wisdom and good qualities manifest
questions.feedback: Goodness illuminates consciousness and leads toward liberation.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.11, what are the symptoms of rajas predominance?
choices: Fruitive activity, restlessness, craving, and endless desire
questions.feedback: Passion drives one toward endless pursuit of temporary goals.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.12 teach about tamas predominance?
choices: Darkness, delusion, negligence, and madness; one becomes bound
questions.feedback: Ignorance creates a state of confusion and spiritual darkness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.13, what happens when one transcends the modes?
choices: One goes beyond birth, death, old age, and is liberated
questions.feedback: Transcending the gunas is the gateway to permanent liberation.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.14, what is the sign of one who has transcended the modes?
choices: One sees the same consciousness in all; is unmoved by change
questions.feedback: Equipoise toward all circumstances indicates transcendence of the gunas.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.15 teach about the path to transcendence?
choices: Those who surrender to me transcend the modes and attain my nature
questions.feedback: Surrender to Krishna is the only means to transcend material nature.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.16, what is promised to those who transcend the modes?
choices: Freed from birth, death, decay, and sorrow; enjoy eternal bliss
questions.feedback: Transcendence grants permanent escape from the cycle of material misery.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.17, what distinguishes sattva from rajas and tamas?
choices: Sattva leads toward liberation; rajas toward fruitive action; tamas toward bondage
questions.feedback: Each mode leads to different spiritual destinations.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.18 teach about the destination of each mode?
choices: All lead to the same place
Sattva goes to the pure planets; rajas to the middle realms; tamas to hell
questions.feedback: One's mode determines the nature of one's next birth and destination.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.19, what is the ultimate path beyond the modes?
choices: One not bewildered by the modes, nor attached; knowing I am eternal, attains me
questions.feedback: Steady faith in Krishna's supremacy transcends all material conditioning.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.20, what characterizes those who have transcended the modes?
choices: They transcend material nature; freed from birth, death, pain, and decay
questions.feedback: Those transcendent to the gunas achieve the highest spiritual position.

questions.prompt: What is the practical application of understanding the gunas?
choices: Recognize them to transcend them and attain Krishna
questions.feedback: Understanding the gunas is essential for spiritual progress.

questions.prompt: According to Chapter 14, how does one escape the cycle?
choices: Through knowledge of the gunas and surrender to Krishna
questions.feedback: Knowledge and devotion together enable transcendence of material nature.

questions.prompt: In BG 14, what is the relationship between the gunas and rebirth?
choices: One's dominant guna determines the nature and quality of next birth
questions.feedback: The modes shape both present and future destinies.

questions.prompt: What does transcending the gunas mean practically?
choices: Performing duty without attachment; seeing all equally
questions.feedback: Transcendence is behavioral equanimity, not rejection of life.

questions.prompt: In Chapter 14, what is Krishna's ultimate promise?
choices: Transcend the gunas; attain my nature; eternal peace awaits
questions.feedback: The highest attainment is becoming one with Krishna's nature.
